nodes.label: Architecture and computer organization
nodes.title: Architecture and computer organization:

nodes.label: Computer abstraction and technology
nodes.title: Computer abstraction and technology:

nodes.label: Performance
nodes.title: Performance: Evaluating the speed and efficiency of computers and programs, considering factors like execution time, memory usage, and power consumption.

nodes.label: Memory Hierarchy
nodes.title: Memory Hierarchy: Memory Hierarchy: The arrangement of different types of memory in a computer system, organized in a hierarchy based on access speed, capacity, and cost.

nodes.label: Memory wall
nodes.title: Memory wall: Memory wall: The growing performance gap between processor speeds and memory access times, leading to slower performance due to memory latency.

nodes.label: Multiprocessors
nodes.title: Multiprocessors: Multiprocessors: Computer systems with multiple processing units (CPUs) that work together to execute tasks concurrently, providing improved performance and scalability.

nodes.label: Flynn taxonomy
nodes.title: Flynn taxonomy: Flynn taxonomy: A classification system proposed by Michael J. Flynn categorizing computer architectures based on the number of instruction streams and data streams.

nodes.label: Amdahl's law
nodes.title: Amdahl's law: Amdahl's law: A principle formulated by Gene Amdahl describing the potential speedup of a program due to parallelization.

nodes.label: Scaling
nodes.title: Scaling: Scaling: The ability of a system to handle increasing workloads by adding resources such as processors, memory, or storage.

nodes.label: Distributed and parallel programming
nodes.title: Distributed and parallel programming:

nodes.label: Parallel and distributed system introduction
nodes.title: Parallel and distributed system introduction: An overview of computing systems that involve multiple processors or computers working together to solve a problem.

nodes.label: Why_parallel_computing?
nodes.title: Why_parallel_computing?: Exploring the motivations behind parallel computing, including the need for increased computational power and efficiency.

nodes.label: Power_wall
nodes.title: Power_wall: The limit on the amount of power that can be dissipated by a microprocessor, which poses a challenge to further increasing clock speeds and performance.

nodes.label: Performance_and_speedup
nodes.title: Performance_and_speedup: Measurement of how well a system performs a task, often quantified by the speedup achieved compared to a reference system or baseline.

nodes.label: Scaling_and_scaling_law
nodes.title: Scaling_and_scaling_law: The study of how system performance changes as the size of the system (such as the number of processors) increases

nodes.label: Amdahl's_law
nodes.title: Amdahl's_law: A formula that predicts the maximum speedup that can be achieved by parallelizing a computation

nodes.label: Gustafson’s_law
nodes.title: Gustafson’s_law: A complementary principle to Amdahl's Law, which argues that larger problems can often be parallelized more effectively

nodes.label: Parallel_Architecture
nodes.title: Parallel_Architecture: The design and organization of hardware systems that support parallel processing, involving multiple processors or processing units.

nodes.label: Michael_Flynn_Texonomy
nodes.title: Michael_Flynn_Texonomy: A classification system proposed by Michael Flynn that categorizes parallel computer architectures based on the number of instruction streams and data streams,resulting in four categories: SISD, SIMD, MISD, and MIMD.

nodes.label: Multi_threading
nodes.title: Multi_threading: A programming model that allows multiple threads of execution to run concurrently within the same process, enabling parallelism and efficient resource utilization.
